threads.com:
This is a place to discuss topics about visual or graphic design. Requests for photoshopping or free work go on /wsr/ - Worksafe Requests or /r/ - Adult Requests as appropriate.

#/gd/ @ irc.rizon.net
#4chan-gd @ irc.freenode.net
http://graphicdesign.wikia.com/

>What literature should I read to get into graphic design?
The sidebar on the /gd/ wiki has plenty of book reccomendations.

>What programs do I need to get started?
-Vector
Adobe Illustrator
Corel Draw
Inkskape

-Bitmap
Adobe Photoshop
Gimp

-3d
Blender
Cinema4d

>Which program is the best for X?
It's usually subjective if you pick a program in each of the right categories above. Use vector programs if your making a logo/icon/illustraton, use bitmap programs if you're messing with a photo or stock image. Gimp, Inkskape, and Blender are free alternatives and have the same function as the paid programs but the paid programs tend to be used more in a professional enviroment.

>What font is used in this image?
Try these sites before posting a tread asking for fonts:
http://whatthefont.com/
http://www.identifont.com/identify.html

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>Can somebody photoshop X? Can somebody make me a logo?
All requests for photoshopping belong on /wsr/ - Worksafe Requests or /r/ - Adult Requests. /gd/ doesn't take requests or do free or even paid work sometimes. However, if you're new at something, asking "HOW can I X?" rather than "CAN YOU make X?" will give you better results.

>Can I post some of my work for critique?
There is usally a critique/What-Are-You-Working-On thread, and that is where work for critique go.

>Can somebody find [font]?
http://www.mediafire.com/download/027xjs3ujvyqxmd/Fonts.zip
also check out your local torrent site or the font-share thread.
Remember to share and not just take. Also remember that using liscensed fonts in commercial works is a bad idea.

>Where can I find inspiration?
http://www.behance.net/
http://dribbble.com/
http://graphicdesign.wikia.com/wiki/Inspiration

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
First off, it's awesome that you're actually *trying* and making an effort. That's the hardest part, anon. I'm proud of you, son.

Now, your pic is pretty much lacking in all of the fundamental laws of design other than it's not a blank jpeg. You need to get familiar with the core fundamental attributes of art/design. The degree to which you attain understanding of these is the degree to which you will be able to create things that resonate with people and that are pleasing to the eye and brain.
If you're a reader then get a book on graphic design fundamentals. If you're not a reader (you should be, anon. The anon who reads lives a thousand lives), then search for "graphic design fundamentals" on the Youtubes.

Some of the fundamental attributes of design are:
* Contrast
* Balance/Symmetry
* Proximity
* Visual hierarchy

Anything that is meant to convey information to another brain needs to be legible, and legibility should take priority over flashiness or 'fun' if you actually want to influence people or inform them through your work. In your case here, the color contrast of the text over the background is low and the font you used (and the fact that it's all caps) makes it very hard to read. Along that line, but not as dire, is the fact that the I2P logo has a lot of similar color to the background so it kinda just melts into the background and isn't as legible.

And finally, young tadpole, a pro tip for future stuff: center-aligned text is almost always the wrong choice. Given any random amateur design, a poster let's say, the one with left-aligned text is going to feel more legible and professional than one with centered shit. Again, that's not gospel and there are times where you want centered shit. But 9/10 times it ain't it.

Uhhh final final thing: whitespace is your best fren. Go forth and kick ass, anon.

>>438517
Because the basic typeface it resembles the Eurostile family (and its direct predecessor) and especially when it's extended people have been conditioned to think "futuristic" for over half a century-

"Eurostile is a popular font, particularly suitable for headings and signs. Its linear nature suggests modern architecture, with an appeal both technical and functional. The squarish shapes with their rounded corners evoke the appearance of television screens of the 1950s and 1960s. It is particularly popular in science fiction artwork and media set or produced in the 1960s and 70s, alongside other graphic design use. Eurostile and its antecedent Microgramma had a near-monopoly on science fiction typefaces through the end of the 20th century, before Ray Larabie, seeing an opening in the market, began designing more modern computer fonts for the genre and distributed them through freeware."

Top one in picrel is Eurostile Extended

>>438139
>What typefaces do you use the most?
Whatever fits the project. You can't cheat sheet good typography, you learn it. That's why there's a gazillion fonts, so you can tailor each project a million different ways.
Get one of the good books on typography, and learn how fonts work, what they're intended for, and the simple theories for it - serif for blocks of text, block fonts for headlines, etc. Develop a taste. Make specimen sheets and see how fonts look in different contexts. Build a library of fonts you're familiar with. I used to hoard fonts, until i realized I only really used a small number of well designed, good looking fonts, now my library is about 100 fonts, and I add decorative fonts as needed.

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com: Creating a holiday themed flyer. How would one go about recreating this kind of hand-stitched crochet look in PS? Texture packs? Or specific layer styles?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>438525
first, thats not crochet, look up cross stitch and needlepoint fonts and youll findxall kinds of lettering and other elements.
That kind of work is based on a grid and is essentially pixellated so to start use a grid layer to establish the layout and size the type "sitching" to fit with it, and if you import any other graphics do the same, and maybe adjust the color depth down so that the pixellated color areas match too.
For other types of needlework like embroidery a line pattern that mimics the stich directions can be overlaid, and similarly a screen/mesh pattern that matches the main grid size can be added over graphic elements to accentuate the look of being made up of blocks, and any areas that don't follow that grid structure removed.

Why is /gd/ so specific to the fairly niche field of graphic design when there's so many other design fields with no place to discuss them on 4chan?
Architecture, industrial/product design, interior design, marketing/advertising, etc. are all closely related fields but don't have a "home" on the site, unless you want to really stretch the "humanities" in /his/ - History & Humanities. I feel like it'd make sense to make /gd/ the de-facto place for those sort of things in the same way /n/ includes urban planning, /co/ includes live action comic adaptations, and /k/ includes military vehicles.
Graphic design really doesn't feel like an expansive enough topic to really *need* a board all to itself, and it's almost /po/ levels of dead. I don't think opening it to other fields of design would degrade board quality or anything.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>438161
>So convert it to LED
Not saying it's impossible but WAY easier said than done for an opaque projector; it's an optical instrument so beam angles matter and even if you found an LED lamp with the right specs the original lamp has 32,000 lumen output and LED equivalents in that range are many hundreds of dollars.
Even with that much output at the lamp those opaque projectors were pretty dim and needed to be in the dark to be useful- for less than the cost of just an LED projector bulb that size you can now buy an entire 1080p LED projector now with built in wifi that will project brighter images in normal room light up to 12' across, and just scan the crappy artwork or take a pic with your phone.
I mean, as a hobby thing knock yourself out, but practically speaking its a ton of work and expense for an antiquated method. Even an overhead projector makes more sense, which is why they replaced opaque projectors that were from the times when quick/cheap transparencies weren't available.
You can get those used for $25-$100 and they are very useful for everything from enlarging images for large scale graphics to doing old school liquid light shows.

threads.sub: Should i drop out graphic design collegue?
threads.com: I started going in a meme university months ago and i thinks it's utter shit, because we hardly ever do things related to the degree and lose so much time that i could use more efficiently if i could be self taught instead. Also, i plan on living from art (self taught) but was pressured by my mother to go an university and chose the graphic design degree, not only because it's a discipline that im genuinely interested but also the thing that i could get the most of. I think that i could save so much money and time if i could drop out and learn all graphic design theory by myself, but i keep hearing that a degree is absolutely necessary to get jobs and be succesful, is that true?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>438053
One, learn how to spell college, you're in college.
Two, graphic design is a huge field. Which part are you going to try and work in?
Three, graphic design is one of the few fields where your portfolio and abilities can still get you hired without a degree, but a degree helps, if you want to rise in the industry to managment, and most art directors and creative directors get degrees in communications and marketing, on top of GD.
Fourth, "graphic design theory" is a bit of bullshit. It's not theory, it's working practices and the tools, with some theory like color theory and such. You can teach yourself, but it's the frameworks you won't learn on your own, or practices, like what the actual production pipeline you'll expected to be part of. it used to be you could get a night time part time gig and learn on the job for shit pay at an ad agency to learn the ropes, but those spots are highly coveted by tons of graduates from design schools who can't get a job. So what makes you more hireable than them, especially since they can walk in, and get the job done with a minimum of questions and mistakes?
I've worked in jobs where I had to help hire more designers. The number one thing we looked at was the portfolio, and if they could get the job done, and we could tell very quickly in the interview if they were clueless how to do that.

How saturated is the market? And specially, would a client prefer someone with a good grasp on graphic design but WITHOUT a degree, or will they prefer someone that has a degree but isn't very good?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>438097
>How saturated is the market?
Very. GD degrees are very popular, and programs in colleges very full. There's a lot of people on the street looking for a job with a mediocre design degree and portfolio, and it seems like that's been true since the rise of desktop publishing.
The key with any creative positions is your brain. You're either good at technical details, like pre-press and production design, when you build up a layout to print properly and conform to styles and such, or you're good at ideas, pikcing colors, building the styles production designers follow, etc. That kind of job is typically not entry level.
>How do you know when they could get the job done?
Asking them questions. Those jobs were in print production, so we could ask them about experience with things like CMYK, color correction, pre-flighting jobs for the press, how to set up bleeds and knock outs, things like that. There are a lot of nuts and bolts parts of print production they don't teach in school, and it's easy to see when someone is in over their head - but we'd also look for people who want to learn it. We'd get a ;lot of prima donna designers who had the attitude of "That's pre-press's problem, not mine" - and we saw that as 'This bitch is gonna cost us thousands in pre-press fees".
These days, you're probably going to be looking at web based design, so it will be different issues.

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com: Institutional logos or whatever this is called. New to /gd/ and planning to make a bunch of these for mundane stuff as practice. What makes these logos appealing and what doesn't? Pls post inpos as well if you have them

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>437592
Most of those would be most accurately described as seals, which are identifiers like logos but more about official formal authentication in the manner of old timey wax seals and signets as opposed to advertising, although they can certainly be used for the latter...the LaSalle one even mimics the squeeze out of wax on its border like a wax seal does.
They also differ from logos in that traditionally they were made more complex to make them harder to fake when wax seals were used as security to confirm that documents, letters, etc hadn't been tampered with. Logos are all about instant recognition without the need to inspect them carefully, seals are supposed to be looked at closely taking time to verify that they're real and intact.
That detail and complexity can work against a logo, and the traditional lettering on an arc can be a real chore to read...but if that's the look you want because it's expected (like for a university or government agency) or it's going to be used as an actual seal, then quick readability is secondary and fine details add to the effect.
Part of that is that fine detail takes time and skill to print, and that's another way to weed out fakes...it costs more but it's a security measure. That's why paper money and stamps and similar valuable certificates are designed with tons of fine detail.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>437610
Forgot to add, for inspiration look at state and corporate seals, both are still used to authenticate documents through embossing which is hard to fake accurately...schools do it with diplomas too, which is part of why they still stick with those traditional styles.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>436951
What kind of graphic design? Web? You don't need a lot of computer. Publishing? You need more. 3D? Even more. High end photo editing and color correction? The most computer you can buy. Large document publishing like catalongs? Even more.

For general Creative Suite tasks, 16 gigs of ram, a GPU newer than 5 years (5 year old Mac would be fine, M1/M2 are fine), and plenty of disk space, not just for installing the Suite, but you should have a decent sized, dedicated swap partition JUST for Adobe on your boot or secondary drive, and as fast as possible. I have a 10gig dedicated partion on an M1, and a 20gig partition on a second internal ssd on my windows laptop. Swap is important, it's one of THE bottlenecks for gd apps - PS stores your current working file, it's save states and history, and everything else while the file is open on the scratch disk. Even back in the HDD days, you'd want a fast drive for it, and not the same HDD as the system, to keep it thrashing around trying to maintain it, and the system caches.

I'll stop there, because if there's one thing that's true on /gd, is that most of you don't really know what graphic design is, how huge a field it is, and overlaps with 3d design and video. Or think that graphic design is painting.

last_replies.com: Not many will care about it if you have 8 years of experience. Just make sure the people interviewing you didn’t go to whatever college you lied about going to.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>437231
I never finished my degree, I dropped out my senior year, so I just list that - I get hired off my work experience and portfolio.
It's not worth lying, because you'll be rejected or fired if found out. When a job listing says "or 4 years equivalent experience", that's for people without a degree - design is one of the few remaining fields where your portfolio can make a degree redundant.
Now, what experience have you had for 8 years? Working for who? And doing what? 8 years is enough to override the degree requirement, unless it's a corporation that insists on a degree on a checklist.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>437231
https://www.diplomacompany.com/
Just make sure you have at least decent knowledge and background in the work you're applying for.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>437256
>design is one of the few remaining fields where your portfolio can make a degree redundant.

This, and the closer you get to actual production areas like printing and packaging, sign and display fabrication, etc. the better the chances are that citing your academic record won't help or may even be seen as a negative...
if only because by the time you have a reasonable amount of work experience you should have learned that that stuff means almost nothing about a person's knowledge of the work at hand or capabilities in perfoming it.
In small shops where design and production aren't rigidly segregated, artist/designers applying for work who cite their academic credentials as if they matter or mean something go to the bottom of the application pile.
